intro: Abutilon confertiflorum, commonly known as the woolly abutilon, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its soft, fuzzy leaves and showy, lantern-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 6 meters. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for drought-tolerant landscaping. Its unique appearance and ability to attract pollinators make it a valuable addition to native plant gardens.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon confertiflorum is primarily native to Central and South America. It is found in countries such as Mexico, Guatemala, Belize, and parts of Central America. This plant thrives in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing in disturbed habitats like roadsides and open forests. It is also present in some areas of the Caribbean. Its distribution includes regions with warm, humid climates and well-drained soils.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon confertiflorum was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and showy flowers. The plant has since become naturalized in several regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal areas and disturbed habitats. However, it is considered a potential weed in some parts of New Zealand.
